title: Participation of women in the Olympics
text:
The rate of participation of women in the Olympic Games has been increasing since their first participation in <a href="1900%20Summer%20Olympics">1900</a>. Some sports are uniquely for women, others are contested by both sexes, while some older sports remain for men only. Studies of media coverage of the Olympics consistently show differences in the ways in which women and men are described and the ways in which their performances are discussed. The representation of women on the <a href="International%20Olympic%20Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> has run well behind the rate of female participation, and it continues to miss its target of a 20% minimum presence of women on their committee.
History of women at the Olympics.
Ancient Olympic Games.
Only men were allowed to attend the <a href="Ancient%20Olympic%20Games">Ancient Olympic Games</a>, other than the priestess of <a href="Demeter">Demeter</a>. The penalty for women attending was death. <a href="Kallipateira%20of%20Rhodes">Kallipateira of Rhodes</a> was threatened with execution merely for attending as her son's trainer.
1900.
The first Olympic Games to feature female athletes was the <a href="1900%20Summer%20Olympics">1900 Games</a> in Paris. <a href="H%C3%A9l%C3%A8ne%20de%20Pourtal%C3%A8s">Hélène de Pourtalès</a> of Switzerland became the first woman to compete at the Olympic Games and became the first female Olympic champion, as a member of the winning team in the first <a href="Sailing%20at%20the%201900%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%201%20to%202%20ton">1 to 2 ton</a> sailing event on May 22, 1900. Briton <a href="Charlotte%20Cooper%20%28tennis%29">Charlotte Cooper</a> became the first female individual champion by winning the <a href="Tennis%20at%20the%201900%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20singles">women's singles tennis competition</a> on July 11. Tennis and golf were the only sports where women could compete in individual disciplines. 22 women competed at the 1900 Games, 2.2% of all the competitors. Alongside sailing, golf and tennis, women also competed in <a href="croquet">croquet</a>.
There were several firsts in the women's golf. This was the first time ever that women competed in the Olympic Games. The women's division was won by <a href="Margaret%20Abbott">Margaret Abbott</a> of <a href="Chicago%20Golf%20Club">Chicago Golf Club</a>. Abbott shot a 47 to win and became the first ever American female to win a <a href="gold%20medal">gold medal</a> in the Olympic Games, though she received a gilded porcelain bowl as a prize instead of a medal. She is also the second overall American woman to receive an Olympic medal. Abbott's mother, <a href="Mary%20Abbott%20%28golfer%29">Mary Abbott</a>, also competed in this Olympic event and finished tied for seventh, shooting a 65. They were the first and only mother and daughter that have ever competed in the same Olympic event at the same time. Margaret never knew that they were competing in the Olympics; she thought it was a normal golf tournament and died not knowing. Her historic victory was not known until <a href="University%20of%20Florida">University of Florida</a> professor Paula Welch began to do research into the history of the Olympics and discovered that <a href="Margaret%20Abbott">Margaret Abbott</a> had placed first. Over the course of ten years, she contacted Abbott's children and informed them of their mother's victory.
1904–1916.
In <a href="1904%20Summer%20Olympics">1904</a>, the women's <a href="Archery%20at%20the%201904%20Summer%20Olympics">archery</a> event was added.
<a href="1908%20Summer%20Olympics">London 1908</a> had 37 female athletes who competed in <a href="Archery%20at%20the%201908%20Summer%20Olympics">archery</a>, <a href="Tennis%20at%20the%201904%20Summer%20Olympics">tennis</a> and <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%201908%20Summer%20Olympics">figure skating</a>.
<a href="1912%20Summer%20Olympics">Stockholm 1912</a> featured 47 women in sports events and saw the addition of <a href="Swimming%20at%20the%201912%20Summer%20Olympics">swimming</a> and <a href="Diving%20at%20the%201912%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%2010%20metre%20platform">diving</a>, as well as the removal of figure skating and archery. The <a href="Art%20competitions%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics">Art competitions</a> that were introduced at those Olympics were also open to women, but full records of the entrants were not kept. 
The <a href="1916%20Summer%20Olympics">1916 Summer Olympics</a> were due to be held in Berlin but were cancelled due to the outbreak of <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>.
1920–1928.
In 1920, 65 women competed at the Games. <a href="Archery%20at%20the%201920%20Summer%20Olympics">Archery</a> was added back to the programme.
<a href="1924%20Summer%20Olympics">Paris 1924</a> saw a record 135 female athletes. <a href="Fencing%20at%20the%201924%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20foil">Fencing</a> was added to the programme, but archery was removed. <a href="1924%20Winter%20Olympics">1924</a> saw the inception of the Winter Olympics where women competed only in the <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%201924%20Winter%20Olympics">figure skating</a>. <a href="Herma%20Szabo">Herma Szabo</a> became the first ever female Winter Olympic champion when she won the <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%201924%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Ladies%27%20singles">ladies' singles competition</a>.
At the <a href="1924%20Summer%20Olympics">1924 Summer Olympics</a> held the same year in Paris, <a href="Fencing%20at%20the%201924%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20foil">women's fencing</a> made its debut with Dane, <a href="Ellen%20Osiier">Ellen Osiier</a> winning the inaugural gold. <a href="Dorothy%20Margaret%20Stuart">Dorothy Margaret Stuart</a> was the first woman to gain a medal in the <a href="Art%20competitions%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics">Arts</a>, winning silver in <a href="List%20of%20Olympic%20medalists%20in%20art%20competitions%23Mixed%20literature">Mixed Literature</a>.
At the 1928 Winter Olympics in <a href="St%20Moritz">St Moritz</a>, no changes were made to any female events. Fifteen year old <a href="Sonja%20Henie">Sonja Henie</a> won her inaugural of three Olympic gold medals.
The Summer Games of the same year saw the debut of women's athletics and gymnastics. In athletics, women competed in the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201928%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20100%20metres">100 metres</a>, <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201928%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20800%20metres">800 metres</a>, <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201928%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%204%20%C3%97%20100%20metres%20relay">4 × 100 metres relay</a>, <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201928%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20high%20jump">high jump</a> and <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201928%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20discus%20throw">discus throw</a>. The 800-metre race was controversial as many competitors were reportedly exhausted or unable to complete the race. Consequently, the IOC decided to drop the 800 metres from the programme; it was not reinstated until 1960. <a href="Halina%20Konopacka">Halina Konopacka</a> of <a href="Poland%20at%20the%201928%20Summer%20Olympics">Poland</a> became the first female Olympic champion in athletics by winning the discus throw. At the <a href="Gymnastics%20at%20the%201928%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20team">gymnastics competition</a>, the host <a href="Netherlands%20at%20the%201928%20Summer%20Olympics">Dutch team</a> won the first gold medal for women in the sport. Tennis was removed from the program.
1932–1936.
For the <a href="1932%20Summer%20Olympics">1932 Summer Olympics</a>, held in Los Angeles, the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201932%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20javelin%20throw">javelin throw</a> and <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201932%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%2080%20metres%20hurdles">80 meters hurdles</a> were added. At the <a href="1936%20Winter%20Olympics">1936 Winter Games</a> in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, women competed in the alpine skiing combined event for the first time, with German <a href="Christl%20Cranz">Christl Cranz</a> winning the gold medal. At the <a href="1936%20Summer%20Olympics">1936 Summer Olympics</a> held in Berlin, <a href="Gymnastics%20at%20the%201936%20Summer%20Olympics">gymnastics</a> returned to the programme for women.
1940–1944.
The <a href="1940%20Winter%20Olympics">1940 Winter Olympics</a> due to be held in Sapporo, <a href="1940%20Summer%20Olympics">1940 Summer Olympics</a> due to be held in Tokyo, <a href="1944%20Winter%20Olympics">1944 Winter Olympics</a> due to be held in Cortina d'Ampezzo and the <a href="1944%20Summer%20Olympics">1944 Summer Olympics</a> due to be held in London were all cancelled due to the outbreak of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. Six female Olympic athletes died due to World War II: 
1948–1956.
At the <a href="1948%20Winter%20Olympics">1948 Winter Olympics</a> in St. Moritz, women made their debut in the <a href="Alpine%20skiing%20at%20the%201948%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20downhill">downhill</a> and <a href="Alpine%20skiing%20at%20the%201948%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20slalom">slalom</a> disciplines, having only competed in the <a href="Alpine%20skiing%20at%20the%201936%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20combined">combined event in 1936</a>. In 1948, women competed in all of the same alpine skiing disciplines as the men. <a href="Barbara%20Ann%20Scott">Barbara Ann Scott</a> of <a href="Canada%20at%20the%201948%20Winter%20Olympics">Canada</a> won the <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%201948%20Winter%20Olympics">ladies' singles figure skating competition</a>, marking the first time a non-European won the gold medal in the event. At the London <a href="1948%20Summer%20Olympics">1948 Summer Olympics</a>, women competed in canoeing for the first time. The women competed in the <a href="Canoeing%20at%20the%201948%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20K-1%20500%20metres">K-1 500 metres discipline</a>. <a href="Alice%20Coachman">Alice Coachman</a> won a gold medal in the women's high jump at the <a href="1948%20Summer%20Olympics">1948 Summer Olympics</a>, marking the first gold medal won by a Black woman for the United States. At the <a href="1952%20Winter%20Olympics">1952 Winter Olympics</a> held in Oslo, women competed in <a href="Cross-country%20skiing%20at%20the%201952%20Winter%20Olympics">cross-country skiing</a> for the first time. They competed in the <a href="Cross-country%20skiing%20at%20the%201952%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%2010%20km">10 kilometre distance</a>. At the <a href="1952%20Summer%20Olympics">1952 Summer Olympics</a> held in Helsinki, women were allowed to compete in <a href="Equestrian%20at%20the%201952%20Summer%20Olympics">equestrian</a> for the first time. They competed in the dressage event which was open to both men and women to compete against one another. Danish equestrian <a href="Lis%20Hartel">Lis Hartel</a> of Denmark won the silver medal in the <a href="Equestrian%20at%20the%201952%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Individual%20dressage">individual competition</a> alongside men. At the <a href="1956%20Winter%20Olympics">1956 Winter Olympics</a> held in Cortina d'Ampezzo, the <a href="Cross-country%20skiing%20at%20the%201956%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Ladies%27%203%20%C3%97%205%20kilometre%20relay">3 × 5 kilometre relay cross country event</a> was added to the program. The <a href="1956%20Summer%20Olympics">1956 Summer Olympics</a> held in Melbourne, had a programme identical to that of the prior Olympiad.
1960–1968.
The <a href="1960%20Winter%20Olympics">1960 Winter Olympics</a> held in Squaw Valley saw the debut of <a href="Speed%20skating%20at%20the%201960%20Winter%20Olympics">speed skating</a> for women. <a href="Helga%20Haase">Helga Haase</a>, representing the <a href="United%20Team%20of%20Germany%20at%20the%201960%20Winter%20Olympics">United Team of Germany</a> won the inaugural gold medal for women in the competition after winning the <a href="Speed%20skating%20at%20the%201960%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20500%20metres">500 metres event</a>. The programme remained the same for the <a href="1960%20Summer%20Olympics">1960 Summer Olympics</a> held in Rome. At the <a href="1964%20Winter%20Olympics">1964 Winter Olympics</a> in Innsbruck, the women's <a href="Cross-country%20skiing%20at%20the%201964%20Winter%20Olympics">5km cross-country skiing</a> event debuted. At the <a href="1964%20Summer%20Olympics">1964 Summer Olympics</a> held in Tokyo, <a href="Volleyball%20at%20the%201964%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20tournament">Volleyball</a> made its debut with the host <a href="Japan%20women%27s%20national%20volleyball%20team">Japanese</a> taking the gold. At the <a href="1968%20Winter%20Olympics">1968 Winter Olympics</a> held in Grenoble, <a href="Luge%20at%20the%201968%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20singles">women's luge</a> appeared for the first time. <a href="Erika%20Lechner">Erika Lechner</a> of <a href="Italy%20at%20the%201968%20Winter%20Olympics">Italy</a> won the gold after <a href="East%20Germany%20at%20the%201968%20Winter%20Olympics">East German</a> racers <a href="Ortrun%20Enderlein">Ortrun Enderlein</a>, <a href="Anna-Maria%20M%C3%BCller">Anna-Maria Müller</a> and <a href="Angela%20Kn%C3%B6sel">Angela Knösel</a> allegedly heated the runners on their sleds and were disqualified. Whether the East Germans actually heated their sleds or if the situation was fabricated by the <a href="West%20Germany%20at%20the%201968%20Winter%20Olympics">West Germans</a> remains a mystery. At the <a href="1968%20Summer%20Olympics">1968 Summer Olympics</a> in Mexico City, women competed in <a href="Shooting%20at%20the%201968%20Summer%20Olympics">shooting</a> for the first time. The women competed in mixed events with the men and were allowed to compete in all seven disciplines.
1972–1980.
The <a href="1972%20Winter%20Olympics">1972 Winter Olympics</a> held in Sapporo saw no additions or subtractions of events for women. At the <a href="1972%20Summer%20Olympics">1972 Summer Olympics</a> held in Munich, <a href="Archery%20at%20the%201972%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20individual">archery</a> was held for the first time since 1920. At the <a href="1976%20Winter%20Olympics">1976 Winter Olympics</a> in Innsbruck, ice dancing was added to the programme. Women competed in three new events at the <a href="1976%20Summer%20Olympics">1976 Summer Olympics</a> held in Montreal. Women debuted in <a href="Basketball%20at%20the%201976%20Summer%20Olympics">basketball</a> and <a href="Handball%20at%20the%201976%20Summer%20Olympics">handball</a>. Women also competed for the first time in <a href="Rowing%20at%20the%201976%20Summer%20Olympics">rowing</a>, participating in six of the eight disciplines. There were no new events for women at the <a href="1980%20Winter%20Olympics">1980 Winter Olympics</a> held in Lake Placid. At the <a href="1980%20Summer%20Olympics">1980 Summer Olympics</a> held in Moscow, <a href="Field%20hockey%20at%20the%201980%20Summer%20Olympics">women's field hockey</a> debuted. The underdog <a href="Zimbabwe%20women%27s%20national%20field%20hockey%20team%20at%20the%201980%20Summer%20Olympics">Zimbabwean team</a> pulled off a major upset, winning the gold, the nation's first ever Olympic medal. However, these Olympics were marred by the <a href="1980%20Summer%20Olympics%20boycott">US-led boycott</a> of the games due to the <a href="Soviet%E2%80%93Afghan%20War">Soviet invasion of Afghanistan</a>.
1984–1992.
The <a href="Cross-country%20skiing%20at%20the%201984%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%2020%20km">women's 20 kilometre cross-country skiing event</a> was added to the programme for the <a href="Cross-country%20skiing%20at%20the%201984%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%2020%20km">1984 Winter Games</a> in Sarajevo. <a href="Marja-Liisa%20Kirvesniemi">Marja-Liisa Hämäläinen</a> of Finland dominated the <a href="Cross-country%20skiing%20at%20the%201984%20Winter%20Olympics">cross-country events</a>, winning gold in all three distances.
Multiple new events for women were competed in at the <a href="1984%20Summer%20Olympics">1984 Summer Olympics</a> in Los Angeles. <a href="Synchronized%20swimming%20at%20the%201984%20Summer%20Olympics">Synchronized swimming</a> made its debut, with only women competing in the competition. The host Americans won gold in both the <a href="Synchronized%20swimming%20at%20the%201984%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20solo">solo</a> and <a href="Synchronized%20swimming%20at%20the%201984%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20duet">duet</a> events. Women also made their debut in cycling, competing in the <a href="Cycling%20at%20the%201984%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20individual%20road%20race">road race</a>. This event was also won by an American, <a href="Connie%20Carpenter-Phinney">Connie Carpenter</a>. Also, <a href="Gymnastics%20at%20the%201984%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20rhythmic%20individual%20all-around">rhythmic gymnastics</a> appeared for the first time with only women competing; the winner was Canadian <a href="Lori%20Fung">Lori Fung</a>. The <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201984%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20marathon">women's marathon</a> also made its first appearance in these Games, with American <a href="Joan%20Benoit">Joan Benoit</a> winning gold in 2:24:52, a time many thought was impossible for women just a few years earlier. These were also the first Games where women competed only against other women in <a href="Shooting%20at%20the%201984%20Summer%20Olympics">shooting</a>. These games were boycotted by the Soviet Union and its satellite states.
There were no new events at the <a href="1988%20Winter%20Olympics">1988 Winter Olympics</a> held in Calgary. At the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, <a href="Table%20tennis%20at%20the%201988%20Summer%20Olympics">table tennis</a> appeared for the first time for both men and women. They competed in the <a href="Table%20tennis%20at%20the%201988%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20singles">singles</a> and <a href="Table%20tennis%20at%20the%201988%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20doubles">doubles</a> disciplines. Also, a female specific sailing event debuted at these Games, the <a href="Sailing%20at%20the%201988%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20470">women's 470 discipline</a>. For the first time women competed in a track cycling event, <a href="Cycling%20at%20the%201988%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20sprint">the sprint</a>.
In 1991, the IOC made it mandatory for all new sports applying for Olympic recognition to have female competitors. However, this rule only applied to new sports applying for Olympic recognition. This meant that any sports that were included in the Olympic programme prior to 1991 could continue to exclude female participants at the discretion of the sport's federation. At the <a href="1992%20Winter%20Olympics">1992 Winter Olympics</a> in Albertville, women competed in <a href="Biathlon%20at%20the%201992%20Winter%20Olympics">biathlon</a> for the first time. The athletes competed in the <a href="Biathlon%20at%20the%201992%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20individual">individual</a>, <a href="Biathlon%20at%20the%201992%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20sprint">sprint</a> and <a href="Biathlon%20at%20the%201992%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20relay">relay</a> disciplines. Freestyle skiing also debuted at the 1992 Games, where women competed in the <a href="Freestyle%20skiing%20at%20the%201992%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20moguls">moguls discipline</a>. <a href="Short%20track%20speed%20skating%20at%20the%201992%20Winter%20Olympics">Short track speed skating</a> first appeared at these Games. Women competed in the <a href="Short%20track%20speed%20skating%20at%20the%201992%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20500%20metres">500 metres</a> and the <a href="Short%20track%20speed%20skating%20at%20the%201992%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%203000%20metre%20relay">3000 metre relay</a>. At the <a href="1992%20Summer%20Olympics">1992 Summer Olympics</a> held in Barcelona, <a href="Badminton%20at%20the%201992%20Summer%20Olympics">badminton</a> appeared on the programme for the first time. Women competed in the <a href="Badminton%20at%20the%201992%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20Singles">singles</a> and <a href="Badminton%20at%20the%201992%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20Doubles">doubles</a> competition. Women also competed in the sport of <a href="Judo%20at%20the%201992%20Summer%20Olympics">judo</a> for the first time at these Games. 35 nations still sent all-male delegations to these Games. 1992 was the last Olympic games that skeet competition opens to both men and women, and the only mixed shooting competition at the Olympics ever won by a woman: <a href="Zhang%20Shan">Zhang Shan</a>.
1994–2002.
At the <a href="1994%20Winter%20Olympics">1994 Winter Olympics</a> in Lillehammer, the <a href="Freestyle%20skiing%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20aerials">aerials discipline</a> of <a href="Freestyle%20skiing%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics">freestyle skiing</a> officially debuted. <a href="Lina%20Cheryazova">Lina Cheryazova</a> of Uzbekistan won the gold medal, which is to date her nation's sole medal at an Olympic Winter Games. <a href="Football%20at%20the%201996%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20tournament">Women's soccer</a> and <a href="Softball%20at%20the%201996%20Summer%20Olympics">softball</a> made their first appearances at the <a href="1996%20Summer%20Olympics">1996 Games</a> in Atlanta, where the hosts won gold in both. At the <a href="1998%20Winter%20Olympics">1998 Winter Olympics</a> in Nagano, <a href="Ice%20hockey%20at%20the%201998%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20tournament">ice hockey</a> (with the United States winning gold) and <a href="Curling%20at%20the%201998%20Winter%20Olympics">curling</a> (with Canada winning gold) debuted for women. Numerous new events made their premieres at the <a href="2000%20Summer%20Olympics">2000 Summer Olympics</a> in Sydney. <a href="Weightlifting%20at%20the%202000%20Summer%20Olympics">Weightlifting</a>, <a href="Modern%20pentathlon%20at%20the%202000%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s">modern pentathlon</a>, <a href="Taekwondo%20at%20the%202000%20Summer%20Olympics">taekwondo</a>, <a href="Triathlon%20at%20the%202000%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s">triathlon</a> and <a href="Gymnastics%20at%20the%202000%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20trampoline">trampoline</a> all debuted in Australia. At the <a href="2002%20Winter%20Olympics">2002 Winter Olympics</a> in Salt Lake City, women's <a href="Bobsleigh%20at%20the%202002%20Winter%20Olympics">bobsleigh</a> made its first appearance. <a href="Jill%20Bakken">Jill Bakken</a> and <a href="Vonetta%20Flowers">Vonetta Flowers</a> of the USA won the <a href="Bobsleigh%20at%20the%202002%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Two-woman">two-woman competition</a>, the sole bobsleigh event for women at the 2002 Games.
2004–2012.
At the <a href="2004%20Summer%20Olympics">2004 Summer Olympics</a> in Athens, women appeared in <a href="Wrestling%20at%20the%202004%20Summer%20Olympics">wrestling</a> for the first time competing in the freestyle weight classes of <a href="Wrestling%20at%20the%202004%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20freestyle%2048%20kg">48 kg</a>, <a href="Wrestling%20at%20the%202004%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20freestyle%2055%20kg">55 kg</a>, <a href="Wrestling%20at%20the%202004%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20freestyle%2063%20kg">63 kg</a> and <a href="Wrestling%20at%20the%202004%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20freestyle%2072%20kg">72 kg</a>. Women also competed in the sabre discipline of fencing for the first time, with <a href="Mariel%20Zagunis">Mariel Zagunis</a> of the USA winning gold. In 2004, women from <a href="Afghanistan%20at%20the%202004%20Summer%20Olympics">Afghanistan</a> competed at the Olympics for the first time in their history after the nation was banned from Sydney 2000 by the IOC due to the <a href="Taliban">Taliban</a> government's <a href="Taliban%20treatment%20of%20women">opposition to women</a> in sports. At the <a href="2006%20Winter%20Olympics">2006 Winter Olympics</a> in Turin, the programme remained unchanged. At the <a href="2008%20Summer%20Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a> in Beijing, a few new events were added. <a href="Cycling%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20BMX">BMX cycling</a> was held for the first time in 2008, debuting with <a href="Cycling%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20BMX">the men's event</a>. Women also competed in the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%203000%20metres%20steeplechase">3000 m steeplechase</a> and the <a href="Swimming%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20marathon%2010%20kilometre">10 kilometre marathon swim</a> for the first time. Baseball and boxing remained the only sports not open to women at these Games.
At the <a href="2010%20Winter%20Olympics">2010 Winter Olympics</a> in Vancouver, <a href="Freestyle%20skiing%20at%20the%202010%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20ski%20cross">ski cross</a> debuted for both women and men. <a href="Ashleigh%20McIvor">Ashleigh McIvor</a> of Canada won the inaugural gold for women in the sport. Controversy was created when women's <a href="ski%20jumping">ski jumping</a> was excluded from the programme by the IOC due to the low number of athletes and participating nations in the sport. A group of fifteen competitive female ski jumpers later filed a suit against the <a href="Vancouver%20Organizing%20Committee%20for%20the%202010%20Olympic%20and%20Paralympic%20Winter%20Games">Vancouver Organizing Committee for the 2010 Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games</a> on the grounds that it violated the <a href="Canadian%20Charter%20of%20Rights%20and%20Freedoms">Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms</a> since men were competing in the same event. The suit failed, with the judge ruling that the situation was not governed by the Charter. The <a href="2012%20Summer%20Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a> saw <a href="women%27s%20boxing">women's boxing</a> make its debut. This, combined with the decision by the IOC to drop baseball from the programme for 2012, meant that women competed in every sport at a Summer Games for the first time. London 2012 also marked the first time that all national Olympic committees sent a female athlete to the Games. <a href="Brunei%20at%20the%202012%20Summer%20Olympics">Brunei</a>, <a href="Saudi%20Arabia%20at%20the%202012%20Summer%20Olympics">Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="Qatar%20at%20the%202012%20Summer%20Olympics">Qatar</a> all had female athletes as a part of their delegations for the first time.
2014–2018.
At the <a href="2014%20Winter%20Olympics">2014 Winter Olympics</a> in Sochi, <a href="Ski%20jumping%20at%20the%202014%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20normal%20hill%20individual">women's ski jumping</a> made its first appearance. <a href="Carina%20Vogt">Carina Vogt</a> of Germany won the first gold medal for women in the sport. The <a href="2016%20Summer%20Olympics">2016 Summer Olympics</a> in Rio de Janeiro saw the first <a href="Rugby%20sevens%20at%20the%202016%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20tournament">rugby sevens competition</a>. The tournament was won by the <a href="Australia%20women%27s%20national%20rugby%20sevens%20team">Australian team</a>. <a href="Golf%20at%20the%202016%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20individual">Golf</a> was also re-added to the programme for the first time for women since 1900. <a href="Inbee%20Park">Inbee Park</a> of South Korea won the tournament. The <a href="2018%20Winter%20Olympics">2018 Winter Olympics</a> in PyeongChang saw the addition of big air snowboarding, mixed doubles curling, mass start speed skating, and mixed team alpine skiing. <a href="Jamie%20Anderson%20%28snowboarder%29">Jamie Anderson</a> of the USA was the silver medalist of the big air, also winning gold in slopestysle, becoming the most medaled female snowboarder at those games.
2020.
<a href="Transgender">Transgender</a> athletes have been permitted at the Olympics since 2004, however, Tokyo 2020 was the first Olympics in which a <a href="trans%20woman">trans woman</a> competed, with <a href="Laurel%20Hubbard">Laurel Hubbard</a> entering the women's super heavyweight <a href="Weightlifting%20at%20the%202020%20Summer%20Olympics%20-%20Qualification">weightlifting</a> event.
Women competed in softball, karate, sport climbing, surfing, and <a href="Skateboarding%20at%20the%202020%20Summer%20Olympics">skateboarding</a> at the <a href="2020%20Summer%20Olympics">2020 Summer Olympics</a> in Tokyo. 
The new sports climbing events - speed climbing, bouldering, and lead climbing - all had men's and women's categories. Several sports, such as <a href="Swimming%20at%20the%202020%20Summer%20Olympics%23Mixed%20events">swimming</a>, introduced mixed events.
The length of tennis matches were changed so that men played three sets, the same as women in all previous Olympics.
The 2020 Olympics was the first Olympics in which women were allowed to compete in canoe sprint. Before this Olympics, women were allowed to do sprint kayak, but not sprint canoe.
The 2020 Olympics was the first Olympics in which there was a women's 1500 meter freestyle swimmming event.
Future Olympics.
The <a href="International%20Ski%20Federation">International Ski Federation</a> has stated that it is aiming to include women's Nordic combined in the Olympic program for the first time at the <a href="2022%20Winter%20Olympics">2022 Winter Olympics</a> in Beijing.
Sports.
Women have competed in the following sports at the Olympic Games.
Gender differences.
Athletics.
In <a href="combined%20events%20at%20the%20Olympics">combined events at the Olympics</a>, women compete in the seven-event <a href="heptathlon">heptathlon</a> but men compete in three more events in the <a href="decathlon">decathlon</a>. A <a href="women%27s%20pentathlon">women's pentathlon</a> was held from 1964 to 1980, before being expanded to the heptathlon.
In <a href="sprint%20hurdles%20at%20the%20Olympics">sprint hurdles at the Olympics</a>, men compete in the 110 metres hurdles, while women cover 100 metres. Women ran 80 metres up to the 1968 Olympics; this was extended to 100 metres in 1961, albeit on a trial basis, the new distance of 100 metres became official in 1969. No date has been given for the addition of the 10 metres. Both men and women clear a total of ten hurdles during the races and both genders take three steps between the hurdles at elite level. Any amendment to the women's distance to match the men's would impact either the athlete technique or number of hurdles in the event, or result in the exclusion of women with shorter strides.
Historically, women competed over <a href="3000%20metres">3000 metres</a> until this was matched to the men's <a href="5000%20metres">5000 metres</a> event in 1996. Similarly, women competed in a <a href="10%20kilometres%20race%20walk">10 kilometres race walk</a> in 1992 and 1996 before this was changed to the standard men's distance of 20 km. The expansion of the women's athletics programme to match the men's was a slow one. Triple jump was added in 1996, hammer throw and pole vault in 2000, and steeplechase in 2008. The sole difference remaining is the men-only <a href="50%20kilometres%20race%20walk">50 kilometres race walk</a> event. While the inclusion of a women's 50 km event has been advocated, proposals have also been mooted to remove the men's event entirely from the Olympics.
Boxing.
At the summer Olympics, men's boxing competitions take place over three three-minute rounds and women's over four rounds of two minutes each. Women also compete in three weight categories against 10 for men.
Canoeing.
Canoeing excluded women at the Olympics from both the sprint and slalom disciplines until Tokyo 2020.
Shooting.
Women are excluded from the 25 metres rapid fire pistol, the 50 metres pistol and the 50 metres rifle prone events. Men are excluded from the 25 metres pistol event. From 1996 to 2004, women participated in the double trap competition. The women's event was taken off the Olympic program after the 2004 Summer Olympics. Final shooting for women was discontinued in international competition as a result.
Road cycling.
Since 1984, when women's cycling events were introduced, the women's road race has been 140 kilometres to the men's 250 kilometres. The time trials are 29 kilometres and 44 kilometres respectively. Each country is limited to sending five men and four women to the Summer Games.
Tennis.
Until the 2020 games, women competed in three-set matches at the Olympics as opposed to five sets for men. The men's matches were shortened for Tokyo 2020.
Soccer.
In Olympic soccer, there is no age restriction for women, whereas the men's teams field under-23 teams with a maximum of three over-aged players.
Gender equality.
Historically, female athletes have been treated, portrayed and looked upon differently from their male counterparts. In the early days of the Olympic Games, many <a href="National%20Olympic%20Committee">NOCs</a> sent fewer female competitors because they would incur the cost of a chaperone, which was not necessary for the male athletes. While inequality in participation has declined throughout history, women are still sometimes treated differently at the Games themselves. For example, in 2012, the <a href="Japan%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Japan women's national soccer team</a> travelled to the Games in economy class, while the men's team travelled in business class. Although women compete in all sports at the summer Olympics, there are still 39 events that are not open to women. Men have to compete in longer and tougher events, such as 110 meters hurdles and tennis matches of five sets, compared to 100 meters hurdles and three sets for women.
Media.
Historically, coverage and inclusion of women's team sports in the Olympics has been limited. It has been shown that commentators are more likely to refer to female athletes using "non-sporting terminology" than they are for men. A 2016 study published by <a href="Cambridge%20University%20Press">Cambridge University Press</a> found that women were more likely to be described using physical features, age, marital status and aesthetics than men were, as opposed to sport related adjectives and descriptions. The same study found that women were also more likely to be referred to as "girls" than men were to be called "boys" in commentary. This disparity in the quality of coverage for women's Olympic sports has been attributed to the fact that 90% of sports journalists are male.
Coverage of women's sports has typically been lower than men's. From 1992 to 1998, American women have always had less raw clock time when being covered on television. Compared to American men, the women have only had 44, 47, and 40 percent of the Olympic television coverage, respectively.
Role of the International Olympic Committee.
The <a href="International%20Olympic%20Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> (IOC) was created by <a href="Pierre%2C%20Baron%20de%20Coubertin">Pierre, Baron de Coubertin</a>, in 1894 and is now considered "the supreme authority of the Olympic movement". Its headquarters are located in <a href="Lausanne%2C%20Switzerland">Lausanne, Switzerland</a>. The title of supreme authority of the Olympic movement consists of many different duties, which include promoting Olympic values, maintaining the regular celebration of the <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympic Games</a>, and supporting any organization that is connected with the Olympic movement.
Some of the Olympic values that the IOC promotes are practicing sport ethically, eliminating discrimination from sports, encouraging women's involvement in sport, fighting the use of drugs in sport, and blending sport, culture, and education. The IOC supports these values by creating different commissions that focus on a particular area. These commissions hold conferences throughout the year where different people around the world discuss ideas and ways to implement the Olympic values into the lives of people internationally. The commissions also have the responsibility of reporting their findings to the <a href="President%20of%20the%20International%20Olympic%20Committee">President of the IOC</a> and its executive board. The President has the authority to assign members to different commissions based on the person's interests and specialties.
The first two female IOC members were the Venezuelan <a href="Flor%20Isava-Fonseca">Flor Isava-Fonseca</a> and the Norwegian <a href="Pirjo%20H%C3%A4ggman">Pirjo Häggman</a> and were co-opted as IOC members in 1981.
The IOC can contain up to 115 members, and currently, the members of the IOC come from 79 different countries. The IOC is considered a powerful authority throughout the world as it creates policies that become standards for other countries to follow in the sporting arena.
Only 20 of the current 106 members of the IOC are women.
Women in Sport Commission.
A goal of the IOC is to encourage these traditional countries to support women's participation in sport because two of the IOC's Olympic values that it must uphold are ensuring the lack of discrimination in sports and promoting women's involvement in sport. The commission that was created to promote the combination of these values was the <a href="International%20Olympic%20Committee%23IOC%20Commissions">Women in Sport Commission</a>. This commission declares its role as "advis[ing] the IOC Executive Board on the policy to deploy in the area of promoting women in sport". This commission did not become fully promoted to its status until 2004, and it meets once a year to discuss its goals and implementations. This commission also presents a Women and Sport Trophy annually which recognizes a woman internationally who has embodied the values of the IOC and who has supported efforts to increase women's participation in sport at all levels. This trophy is supposed to symbolize the IOC's commitment to honoring those who are beneficial to gender equality in sports.
Another way that the IOC tried to support women's participation in sport was allowing women to become members. In 1990, <a href="Flor%20Isava%20Fonseca">Flor Isava Fonseca</a> became the first woman elected to the executive board of the IOC. The first American woman member of the IOC was <a href="Anita%20DeFrantz">Anita DeFrantz</a>, who became a member in 1986 and in 1992 began chairing the prototype of the <a href="Softball%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics%23Inclusion%20on%20the%20Olympic%20programme">IOC Commission on Women in Sport</a>. DeFrantz not only worked towards promoting gender equality in sports, but she also wanted to move toward gender equality in the IOC so women could be equally represented. She believed that without equal representation in the IOC that women's voices would not get an equal chance to be heard. She was instrumental in creating a new IOC policy that required the IOC membership to be composed of at least 20 percent women by 2005. She also commissioned a study conducted in 1989 and again in 1994 that focused on the difference between televised coverage of men's and women's sports. <a href="Gender%20inequality">Inequality</a> still exists in this area, but her study was deemed to be eye opening to how substantial the problem was and suggested ways to increase reporting on women's sporting events. DeFrantz is now head of the Women in Sport Commission.
The IOC failed in its policy requiring 20 percent of IOC members to be women by 2005. By June 2012, the policy had still not been achieved, with only 20 out of 106 IOC members women, an 18.8 percent ratio. Only 4 percent of <a href="National%20Olympic%20Committee">National Olympic Committee</a>s have female presidents.
Impact of the Women's World Games.
Background.
In 1919, French translator and amateur rower, <a href="Alice%20Milliat">Alice Milliat</a> initiated talks with the IOC and <a href="International%20Association%20of%20Athletics%20Federations">International Association of Athletics Federations</a> with the goal of having women's athletics included at the 1924 Summer Olympics. After her request was refused, she organized the first "<a href="1921%20Women%27s%20Olympiad">Women's Olympiad</a>", hosted in <a href="Monte%20Carlo">Monte Carlo</a>. This would become the precursor to the first Women's World Games. The event was seen as a protest against the IOC's refusal to include females in athletics and a message to their President <a href="Pierre%20de%20Coubertin">Pierre de Coubertin</a> who was opposed to women at the Olympics. Milliat went on to found the <a href="International%20Women%27s%20Sports%20Federation">International Women's Sports Federation</a> who organized the first Women's World Games.
The Games.
The first ever "Women's Olympic Games" were held in <a href="1922%20Women%27s%20World%20Games">Paris in 1922</a>. The athletes competed in eleven events: <a href="60%20metres">60 metres</a>, <a href="100-yard%20dash">100 yards</a>, <a href="Sprint%20%28running%29%23Historical%20and%20uncommon%20distances">300 metres</a>, <a href="Middle-distance%20running%231000%20m">1000 metres</a>, <a href="Relay%20race">4 x 110 yards relay</a>, <a href="Hurdling">Hurdling</a> 100 yards, <a href="high%20jump">high jump</a>, <a href="long%20jump">long jump</a>, <a href="standing%20long%20jump">standing long jump</a>, <a href="javelin">javelin</a> and <a href="shot%20put">shot put</a>. 20,000 people attended the Games and 18 world records were set. Despite the successful outcome of the event, the IOC still refused to include women's athletics at the 1924 Summer Olympics. On top of this, the IOC and IAAF objected to the use of the term "Olympic" in the event, so the IWSF changed the name of the event to the Women's World Games for the 1926 version. The <a href="1926%20Women%27s%20World%20Games">1926 Women's World Games</a> would be held in Gothenburg, Sweden. The discus throw was added to the programme. These Games were also attended by 20,000 spectators and finally convinced the IOC to allow women to compete in the Olympics in some athletics events. The IOC let women compete in 100 metres, 800 metres, 4 × 100 metres relay, high jump and discus throw in 1928. There would be two more editions of the Women's World Games, <a href="1930%20Women%27s%20World%20Games">1930</a> in Prague and <a href="1934%20Women%27s%20World%20Games">1934</a> in London. The IWSF was forced to fold after the <a href="Government%20of%20France">Government of France</a> pulled funding in 1936. <a href="Pierre%20de%20Coubertin">Pierre de Coubertin</a>, founder of the International Olympic Committee, was quoted with saying "I do not approve of the participation of women in public competitions. In the Olympic Games, their primary role should be to crown the victors."
